Speaker: Vito
Text: My name is Vito Scaletta. I was born in Sicily in 1925. That little guy’s me. I’m standing there with my parents and my sister Francesca in front of our old house. I don’t really remember too much about the old country… except that we were pretty hard up. And then one day, my father decided it was time to move away. Away from Sicily. Across the ocean to start a new life in America. Never in my life had I seen anything as fantastic as Empire Bay. It was beautiful. On the other hand, I’d never seen anything filthier or more disgusting than our new shithole of an apartment. "The American Dream." It was more like a nightmare. My father started working at the part for the guy who arranged our emigration. It was back-breaking work, and what little money he made mostly went towards booze. Eventually parents sent me to school. I had to learn English, ‘and I sure as hell wasn’t gonna do that in a neighbourhood full of italians. That’s where I met Joe…

Speaker: Joe
Text: C’mon, Vito. Hurry it up. We ain’t got all night.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Over time, Joe and I got to be best friends. And since we both poor, and there were wasn’t much work around, we started a little business of our own…

Speaker: Policeman
Text: Freeze! Police!

Speaker: Joe
Text: Vito! This way! Throw me the bag!

Speaker: Policeman
Text: Stop or I’ll shoot! OK, ye bastard, spread yer legs and put your hands on the fence!

Speaker: Joe
Text: Fuck, I’m sorry, Vito.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Well, that one time it didn’t work out so good. The year was 1943. America was at war end the Army was lookin’ for guys who spoke the language to help with the invasion of Sicily. I was eighteen and anything seems better than jail. Who say you can’t go home again?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Operation Husky: I was assigned to the 504th Parachute Infantry. On the 11th of July we were supposed to be dropped over of the southern coast of Sicily, but we got hit by flak to bail out - way behind enemy lines. Only three of us made it. If it wasn’t for the local resistance we wouldn’t have had the chance. So when Mussolini’s soldiers came into the town and started rounding everybody up, we decided to return the favor.

Speaker: Mussolini’s Officer
Text: Why does no one talk? Now this man must die… Ha, ha?

Speaker: Villager
Text: No, no please… uh, uh…

Speaker: Officer
Text: Alright, Scaletta. Take the shot.
[Scaletta eliminate the soldiers of Mussolini and the unit move into the building.]

Speaker: Mussolini’s Soldier
Text: So, your traitors!

Speaker: Corporal
Text: We gotta clear that balconies, Scaletta! They’re falling back. Let’s move. On me! Get down! Get down! Shit! Ahhh! Shhthhhh! Fuuuuck. We must get inside and save the prisoners before the army arrives.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Corporal - this guy’s sayin’ there’s more troops headed this way.

Speaker: Corporal
Text: Terrific. Alright, you and Williams take out that machine gun nest, then find the prisoners. We’re gonna need every man we can get. Ain’t gettin’ through this way.

Speaker: Soldier
Text: Looks like we found the machine gun!

Speaker: Corporal
Text: If you got a grenade, Scaletta, this would be a GREAT FUCKING TIME to use it!

Speaker: Soldier
Text: Watch it!

Speaker: Corporal
Text: Put a grenade through the window!
[After the explosion that costs lives.]

Speaker: Corporal
Text: Scaletta, you alive?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah. Just about.

Speaker: Corporal
Text: Well, then get off your ass and let’s move it. Grab all the ammo you can carry. This might be our last chance.

Speaker: Soldier
Text: Wh-hoo! Look at this shit!

Speaker: Corporal
Text: On the stairs!

Speaker: Soldier
Text: Hey, greaseballs, catch! No offense, Scaletta.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Must have the prisoners upstairs.

Speaker: Mussolini’s Soldier
Text: Kill the hostages!

Speaker: Soldier
Text: Right behind you, man.

Speaker: Corporal
Text: The door Scaletta. Kick it in!

Speaker: Mussolini’s Officer
Text: Surrender! Or I’ll blow his brains out!

Speaker: Corporal
Text: Shit, looks like we’re goin’ this way. Come on then.

Speaker: Soldier
Text: Ah shit! How many of these fuckers are there?

Speaker: Corporal
Text: Who gives a fuck?! Just keep shooting!

Speaker: Soldier
Text: What in the hell’s it look like I’m doing?!

Speaker: Vito
Text: More shootin’, less talkin’.

Speaker: Soldier
Text: Hey, fine by me asshole… Shit, this balcony isn’t gonna work.

Speaker: Corporal
Text: We gotta keep movin’, let’s get inside. Get inside, Scaletta! You’re gonna die out here!

Speaker: Soldier
Text: More fascists are coming!
[Vito takes a machine gun and start shooting.]

Speaker: Corporal
Text: More of ‘em down by the church. Let ‘em have it! Ahhhhh, shit, they got artillery! Get inside, now!

Speaker: Don Calo
Text: Don’t shoot, boys! You know me. I have an offer for you. The war is over!

Speaker: Mussolini’s Soldier 1
Text: The Americans have come to liberate us. They are our friends. They will rid of Mussolini for us.

Speaker: Mussolini’s Soldier 2
Text: Who the hell is that? You know him?!

Speaker: Mussolini’s Soldier 1
Text: Everyone knows him. Don Calo, he’s a man of honor.

Speaker: Don Calo
Text: If you don’t do anything stupid, you can go home to your families today. You’re safe. I guarantee this! You know you can trust me. What do you say?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Don Calo, the head of the Sicilian mob. An entire garrison of troops surrendered that day. Why? Because he told ‘em to.
[Vito returns to Empire Bay.]

Speaker: Vito
Text: A few years later, the Nazis put a bullet in me. I was in a hospital for a bit, then I got a month’s leave, so I could go home… at least for a little while.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Vito! Over here!

Speaker: Vito
Text: Joe!

Speaker: Joe
Text: He, heh, hey! Welcome home, buddy!

Speaker: Vito
Text: How’d you know?

Speaker: Joe
Text: I got my sources. Come on, let’s take a ride.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Nice car.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Comes with the territory. I know you’re itching to get home, but first let’s get a beer.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah, sure.

Speaker: Joe
Text: There it is… Empire Bay. Tell the truth. You miss it?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Hey does a bear shit in the woods? Not like this plate ever done me any favors, but anything’s better than a foxhole. What’s with this shitty weather?

Speaker: Joe
Text: They’re saying this is the coldest winter on record. Papers say it’s gonna keep up like this for weeks. Don’t worry though, a drink’ll worm you right up. How long’s it been since we had a drink together, Vito? Two years?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Almost three. Tony Sachelli’s party, right?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Come on, Vito, came on. The last drink we had together was right after your old man’s funeral, right before you shipped out. You remember?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Ah, five minutes, we’re already talking about my deadbeat father can we change the subject please?

Speaker: Joe
Text: So tell me pal, what was it like over there anyway? I kept reading the papers to see what was going on, and you know how much I hate reading…

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah I know.

Speaker: Joe
Text: You guys kicked Mussolini’s ass, right?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Ah sort of… We had a little help from a guy named Don Calo.

Speaker: Joe
Text: No shit! Don Calo I heard of him!

Speaker: Vito
Text: Really?

Speaker: Joe
Text: You bet. I know guys like him over here. Wiseguys? You work for them, you’re set. You fuck with ‘em, you die.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Nice to see you been busy!

Speaker: Joe
Text: Yeah, and I heard you got a medal, right?

Speaker: Vito
Text: From Old Man Patton himself.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Whoa, so you’re a real war hero, huh! Hahaha… And then what, you screwed a couple of Sicilian broads and came home?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah, right…

Speaker: Joe
Text: Hehehe! The old country. Over here you can screw anything with a heartbeat - No one gives a shit. What a country! Here’s do the US of A, and to having you back home.
[They come to a bar.]

Speaker: Vito
Text: Salut!

Speaker: Joe
Text: A’salute Cent’anni. So how come you’re back? They let you out early for good behavior?

Speaker: Vito
Text: No, I took a bullet couple of months back, spend some time in a hospital, and no I’m on leave.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Wait, wh-wh-wh-hold it… you mean you gotta go back?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Hehe, what did you think? The war ain’t over yet.

Speaker: Joe
Text: You don’t want to go back, do you?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Ah, of course not, but what can I do?

Speaker: Joe
Text: One minute! Wait right here.  Hey, Giuseppe, it’s Joe. Remember last week, you know… the guy, the guy’s name is Vito Scaletta… Thanks, Giuseppe. Alright, I’ll see you later.

Speaker: Joe
Text: OK, listen up. It "appears" that your injury is much more "serious" than it first appeared and the doctors say you can’t fight no more.

Speaker: Vito
Text: What!? Oh, whoa, whoa - Did you just…!?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Like I said, I know people. You get all the official paperwork tomorrow. When it comes to the right stamps and signatures, it’s just a question of money…

Speaker: Vito
Text: You’re kidding me, right? Isn’t that a bit risky? It’s me that could end up in the slammer, you know. And how am I going to pay for it?

Speaker: Joe
Text: I got it covered. Think of it as a welcome home present. And don’t worry. The documents will be clean. Trust me.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Well… thanks…

Speaker: Joe
Text: You’re welcome, come un frate, you’re like a brother to me… Now you can start thinking about what you’re gonna do next.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Sure, but first I gotta go home.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Alright. You want a ride?

Speaker: Vito
Text: No thanks. I want to walk around a little, see what’s changed since I been gone.

Speaker: Joe
Text: No problem. Say hello to your sister for me, come see me tomorrow. We got a lot to talk about.

Speaker: Vito
Text: I can’t believe you just got me out of the service. Thanks again.

Speaker: Joe
Text: No problem.

Speaker: Vito
Text: I’ll catch up with you tomorrow.
[Vito exits the bar and the scene ends. In the next scene, he rides on a taxi to his mother’s house.]

Speaker: Taxi driver
Text: Here we are.

Speaker: Vito
Text: All right, thanks. Keep the change.
[Getting out of the car, he walks down a narrow alley and goes up to a shabby house with a lot of tenants. Vito presses the doorbell and an elderly woman comes out to the stairwell.]

Speaker: Vito
Text: Hi, Momma. I’m back.

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: Vito! Vito, my boy! My boy is home! I thought I never see you again! Francesca and me, we wait and we wait for you!

Speaker: Vito
Text: Hey, sis, what’s going on? C’mere…

Speaker: Francesca
Text: Vito! Oh, I’m so glad you’re finally home!

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: Sit down, sit down, you must be hungry, Vito. Francesca made you a special dinner. Zuppa di pollo… (Chicken soup…) It’s good for you.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Wow, looks good, Frankie…

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: It’s a shame your papa didn’t live to see this. He would be so proud,Vito.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah, sure…

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: Vito! You know better.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Sorry, Momma, sorry… Bless us, O Lord! And these Thy gifts for which we are about to receive from Thy bounty, through Christ our Lord. Amen.
[After dinner.]

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: You should get some sleep. Your room is just like you left it.

Speaker: Vito
Text: I’ll see you two in the morning.

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: Sleep well, mio bambino .

Speaker: Vito
Text: This ain’t gonna wt it, I gotta find a place to stay.

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: So you have to go back soon?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Actually, uh, it looks like I won’t. Uh, Joe’s taking care of it for me.

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: JOE! Do you want to get into trouble again?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Momma, would you rather me go back and get shot again?

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: No, no…

Speaker: Vito
Text: Exactly. Joe probably saved my life.

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: Promise that you won’t get in any more trouble with that Joe. You know, your papa used to work for this man at the waterfront named Pappalardo. He’s in the union. You could talk to him, work hard like you were your papa. Talk to him. Please, promise me you go talk to him today.

Speaker: Vito
Text: OK, Momma, OK. I promise.

Speaker: Vito’s Mom
Text: Grazie o Dio!
[On the street near the house.]

Speaker: Mafioso
Text: I don’t care if you gotta sell everything you got -

Speaker: Francesca
Text: I’m sorry. We’ll get the money, I promise.

Speaker: Vito
Text: What the hell’s going on here?!

Speaker: Francesca
Text: Vito.

Speaker: Mafioso
Text: You mind your business, asshole!

Speaker: Vito
Text: Oh yeah?
[He pushes him and the fight begins. Vito teaches this idiot a lesson.]

Speaker: Mafioso
Text: Aw, fuck this!

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah, that’s right, get the fuck out of here!

Speaker: Mafioso
Text: You’re gonna be sorry the both of you’s!

Speaker: Vito
Text: What the hell was that all about?

Speaker: Francesca
Text: I’m sorry, Vito. We didn’t want to bother you with this.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Bother me? Bother me with what? C’mon, tell me what’s going on here, Frankie!

Speaker: Francesca
Text: Right before he died, Papa borrowed money – a lot of money – from a loan shark, thinking he’d get a better job and pay him back. We found out right after you left for the war.

Speaker: Vito
Text: How much?

Speaker: Francesca
Text: Two thousand dollars.

Speaker: Vito
Text: What? Shit…

Speaker: Francesca
Text: The worst thing is this guy wants it all back by the end of this week, otherwise… the debt goes up again.

Speaker: Vito
Text: I ain’t gonna make that kind of money working at the port. Who is this guy?

Speaker: Francesca
Text: I don’t know, Momma won’t tell me. It’s OK, Vito. We’ll manage somehow.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Don’t worry. I’ll take rare of this… I promise.

Speaker: Francesca
Text: Thanks, Vito. Take care of yourself.

Speaker: Vito
Text: I gotta get my hands on two grand, last… I bet Joe could help me out.
[He goes to Joe’s place.]

Speaker: Vito
Text: Excuse me, ma’am? Um, do you know where Joe Barbaro lives?

Speaker: Old lady
Text: To the right of the stairs. And tell him that racket last night has to stop if he don’t like it he can find another place to live.
[From Joe’s apartment loud music be heard. Vito knocks. Joe open the door in his underwear.]

Speaker: Vito
Text: Oh, is this a bad time?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Haha what are you kidding, no not at all! Come on in, let’s talk.
[Joe looks at the old lady and makes jerking gesture in the air.]

Speaker: Old lady
Text: Ugh… you disgusting pig.

Speaker: Joe
Text: I picked up these broads on my way back from the store. I’ve been waiting for you. Alright, girls, that’s it for now. I got business. Stop by tomorrow, OK? We’ll pick up where we left off. Chop chop.

Speaker: Whore
Text: Come on, Joey! Why do we have to stop when we can all have fun?

Speaker: Joe
Text: The fun’s over, baby, later, I said. Me and Vito here haven’t seen each other for a long time. We got a lot of catching up to do.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Looks like you’re doing OK, Joey boy.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Not bad. I tell you, that little Spanish broad is fucking wild. So how’d it go at home?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Good. Momma wasn’t thrilled when I mentioned your name, though? You know how she is. She wants me to get a straight job.

Speaker: Joe
Text: You gonna look for one?

Speaker: Vito
Text: I don’t know, but I sure as hell ain’t gonna make the same mi The my old man did. I got to pay all his debts then get back on my feet and get my own place. I need to make some real money and punching a clock ain’t gonna rut it.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Hey, you can stay with me as long as you need to. And we’ll find you a tab where you can make good money without killing yourself, alright?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Music to my ears. Right now I’m living off the twenty bucks the state gives me every week.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Hehehe, I know lots of people who pay well for, uh, "risky" jobs, so to speak… I’m sure I con line something up for my oldest friend. The working man’s a sucker, that’s for damn sure.

Speaker: Vito
Text: You said it.

Speaker: Joe
Text: OK, step one - I gotta introduce you to Giuseppe so we can pick up them discharge papers. Let’s go.

Speaker: Vito
Text: You made enough cash for all this in the last three years?

Speaker: Joe
Text: More like the last three months. I barely had time to furnish the place.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Three months? Holy shit…

Speaker: Joe
Text: So, you though about what you gonna do now?

Speaker: Vito
Text: You said you were gonna introduce me to that guy Giuseppe.
[They go to Joe’s garage.]

Speaker: Vito
Text: Hey, uh, you think I could, uh.

Speaker: Joe
Text: What - drive Vito? The roads are icy, and you ain’t never drove a car before.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Joe I was driving almost the whole time I was over there!

Speaker: Joe
Text: Yeah, but this ain’t no tank, Vito. This rs one of the nicest cars money can buy…

Speaker: Vito
Text: I didn’t drive a tank, I drove a jeep.

Speaker: Joe
Text: What the hell’s a jeep?

Speaker: Vito
Text: It’s a… never mind. You gonna let me drive or what?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Alright, alright here’s the keys. Just be fucking careful. Alright, when it’s cold as fuck outside, you gotta give it a little more gas than usual. That’s the pedal over there on the right…

Speaker: Vito
Text: I know, Joe, I know…

Speaker: Joe
Text: OK, now make a right here. Then just go straight for a while. Hey, whoa, whoa, whoa! Slow it down a bit! No need to get pulled over for no reason. Hey Vito! You know that time it is?

Speaker: Vito
Text: It’s daytime, how the fuck should I know?

Speaker: Joe
Text: It’s time for you to get your own fucking car.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah, I’d love to if I could afford one.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Who says you’re gonna pay for it? You know, you wasn’t kidding. They really taught you to drive over there. At least something good come out of it.
[They stop in the alley behind the houses.]

Speaker: Joe
Text: Ooh get a load of that baby.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Nice, that’s a ’42 Jefferson.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Beautiful car like that, it’d be a shame to smash the window. You should grab yourself same look picks over at Giuseppe’s.  Welcome to Giuseppe’s General Store, a thieves’ paradise… You name it, he’s got it. He even sells phony gun permits and discharge papers for guys tired of getting their asses shot all…

Speaker: Joe
Text: Hey. Giuseppe! I brought you a new customer.

Speaker: Giuseppe
Text: Hello, Joe. He’s, uh, straight up, right?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Yes, sir, all the way. This here’s Vito, my oldest friend. This is Giuseppe, the best safecracker in Empire Bay.

Speaker: Giuseppe
Text: Retired, please. How are you? The papers for you?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Yeah, they are. You got ‘em finished already?

Speaker: Giuseppe
Text: It was a pain in the ass, but sure they’re done.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Well, thanks. This really gonna work?

Speaker: Giuseppe
Text: Nobody from the army will bother you again, trust me.

Speaker: Joe
Text: You see? What’d I tell you? Here’s the money. Take your papers, Vito.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Uh, we need a set of fork picks, too.

Speaker: Joe
Text: That we do. And guess who’s payin’ for them.

Speaker: Giuseppe
Text: Grazie. You can test it right now. Here, take this this lock. You just need to to insert the pick into the lock and tilt off the pins. You use the wrench to hold the pins one by one. When all of the pins are set, just turn the wrench and the lock, she opens. Easy.

Speaker: Joe
Text: See you around, Giuseppe. Sia benedira .

Speaker: Vito
Text: Easy, huh?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Don’t worry, you’ll get the hang of it. I do it all the time when I look my keys in the car. Okay, you still feel like snagging that car?

Speaker: Vito
Text: You kidding me? Absolutely.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Well, here’s your chance.
[Vito picks the car’s lock and then sits in it with Joe. The police notices them.]

Speaker: Joe
Text: Step on it!

Speaker: Vito
Text: Oh fuck, that was dose.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Yeah, well, it’s not over yet! Lose ‘em quirk! Alright. Looks like we lost him. So how do ya like the car?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Not too bad. I think I’ll keep it.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Alright, let’s go find ourselves a body shop. They provide the kind of services we’re looking for.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Hey that don’t sound cheap.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Don’t worry about it, I got it covered. Just find any body shop. I know the guy who runs ‘em.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Here, park right here in front of the garage door.
[Vito drives into the garage where some guy changes his plates.]

Speaker: Joe
Text: Alright, next you should introduce yourself to Mike Bruski. He’ll probably have some work for you.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Alright, where is he?

Speaker: Joe
Text: He owns a junk yard over in Riverside. You can’t miss it.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Hey, who’s that guy back there?

Speaker: Joe
Text: What guy?

Speaker: Vito
Text: The guy at the body shop.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Oh, Tommy. He’s my buddy’s nephew. He’s kinda quiet, but let me tell you, the kid’s some hell of a dancer. Saw him at the old dance hall in Oyster Bay a couple of weeks ago. He had all the broads going nuts.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Do I detect a hint of, uh, jealousy?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Are you kidding? I don’t need no dance moves. I got charm, my friend. Here, I’ll give you some of my lines, so maybe you won’t have to spend so many nights with Rosie Palm and her live sisters. Hey here’s one. Hey, is that a mirror in your pocket? ‘Cos I can see myself in your pants.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Ha, ha, ha.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Ah here, I got another one. If I could rearrange the alphabet I’d put U and I together.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Oh, oh, come on.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Or this one never fails. Hey, baby, that’s a nice outfit. It would look good crumbled up at the food of my bed in the morning.

Speaker: Vito
Text: And this works for you?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Aww here, here’s a good one. Hey, do you know the difference between sex and conversation? No? You wanna go back to my place and talk?

Speaker: Vito
Text: You got problems you know that?

Speaker: Joe
Text: How about this one? Why don’t we go back to my house and play house? You’ll be the door and I’ll slam you.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Oh that was bad.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Hey, when you measure seven salt, you don’t have to be good with words, you get my drift? That’s Mike’s junkyard for there. Just drive through the gate.
[They come to the place.]

Speaker: Mike
Text: Hey, look who’s here.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Hey, Mikey Boy, what’s going on? Shit, Mike! You could wash your fucking hands once in a while. Now I need a fucking bath!

Speaker: Mike
Text: Hey, I been working. Working people occasionally get dirty, you know. Besides, I just wiped them all.

Speaker: Joe
Text: With what? The same fucking rag you use to clean the toilet, you filthy fuck?

Speaker: Mike
Text: Put a lid on it. What are you, from the health department or do you want to do some business?

Speaker: Joe
Text: Business, of course. This here’s my friend Vito. Vito, this is Mike Bruski; but don’t shake his hand, I ain’t got that much soap at home.

Speaker: Mike
Text: Nice to meet you, Vito.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Uh, me and Vito go way back. Is just come back from overseas and he needs some cash. So, I figure he can help with your, uh, "supply problem". I can vouch for him.

Speaker: Mike
Text: Uh huh. OK. Joe told you about our side business, right?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Mike
Text: I only want regular cars, nothing fancy. You get a cut of every car. I take as many as I can handle. And don’t bring no cops around, OK? If they follow you here, I don’t know your ass from Jesus. You get me?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Got it.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Goddammit Mike! You put your grubby mitts on my fucking coat! I paid a fortune for this thing!

Speaker: Mike
Text: Alright, calm down or I’ll stick ‘em up your ass, your sissy.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Do you know, what dry cleaning costs these days?

Speaker: Mike
Text: Jesus Christ.

Speaker: Joe
Text: Plenty, and who knows if they can even get this filth out.

Speaker: Mike
Text: Will you shut up? Vito listen to me - I need at Walter coupe today. I got a few people looking for parts, but I can’t find a car.

Speaker: Joe
Text: …Because you don’t know where to look’ Every time I drive down Hunters I see one parked by a bar there I think the plate is called The Lone Star.

Speaker: Vito
Text: Isn’t that a mulligan neighborhood. I’ll stick out like a sore thumb.

Speaker: Mike
Text: Alright look, I’ll give you three hundred and fifty bucks for it. It’s worth the risk, right?

Speaker: Vito
Text: Four hundred.

Speaker: Mike
